job_title: IT Help Center Student Assistant in Northridge, CA
pros: - Trained to have a better understanding of campus technology and what is offered for free to students. - Friendly work environment. - Flexibility of scheduling for school work loads like finals, projects, etc. - Has occasional high volume of end-user's to test skills/experience under pressure. - Almost always can get max hours per week (19.5~20). - Down time to complete school work if scheduled in-person and is a slow day. - Being a part-time student is the minimum requirement to be apply.
cons: - Some large scale changes occur typically semi-annually (semester start/end) between terms which will lead to a large volume of end-user's. Ex: Alumni no longer having life-long access to their student emails.

review_title: Student-centered university that serves primarily academically underprepared students
pros:
- Highly diverse diversity of students (Hispanic Serving Institution, was and may again be an AANAPISI (Asian American, Native American, & Pacific Islander-Serving Institution), and the largest population of Armenian students at any university in the U.S. 
- Smaller classes
- Caring faculty and staff, particularly for a very large university.
- Many strong academic majors and very competent faculty
- Very strong support for those who wish to prepare for graduate school.
- Many mentorship programs.
- Anyone who wants to can have an involved, enriching experience at this university.
- Attending this university and earning a degree has resulted in upward mobility financially.
- Health care benefits at retirement that extend into a Medicare supplement plan paid by CalPERS
- University Student Union creates environments that are cutting edge and meaningful for students to become involved and become leaders on campus or participants in many programming options.
- Stellar facilities in the Student Recreation Center that has energized that side of campus since opening in 2012. (On average, many thousands of students used daily pre-pandemic.
cons:
- It is hot hot hot in the summer and fall.
- Parking can be challenging. There are many public transportation options, but they are much slower and few people (relatively) choose them.
- Compensation is less than some other universities, but the retirement benefits (defined benefit and healthcare supplement to Medicare are the best around including the UC system and community colleges)

job_title: Student Marketing Project Assistant in Northridge, CA
pros: This review is for the University Student Union (USU) at CSUN. I was first employed by the SRC, then later by the Marketing Department. Both are completely different experiences and styles of management. The 5-star rating is only for the Marketing Department by the way. There, I had the best experience while in my undergrad. Best manager and mentor, whom sadly, is now retiring. However the people there truly make the experience the best. Such a wholesome, fun, and amiable bunch. Not to mention very creative, because, obviously. Some of my best memories are our yearly offsite reunion with current student workers and previous working alumni. Others include tabling for the student marketing events and joining in on all the fun - from crafting to photo booths with my coworkers. And the free food.
cons: Cons wise, I truly can't say a single negative thing about the USU Marketing Department. If I could rate this experience 10 stars out of 5, best believe I would.

review_title: Great place to work at CSUN
pros: Great environment, great people, commitment to diversity
cons: Low pay, seems to be dependent on funding

pros:
1. Great benefits and perks
2. You belong to a union (but they are lazy)
3. State retirement pension
4. Sense of community
5. Staff and students are very diverse
6. Nice campus
7. You (or immediate family members) can go to school for only $3.00 a unit if you are an undergrad or grad student
cons:
1. Lazy union that only wants money
2. Lazy staff and managers- no one intends to go the extra mile and very bureaucratic 
3. Low salaries for staff, but not for Directors or higher
4. Management plays favorites, and there is lots of nepotism
5. The higher you go up the corporate ladder, the less diverse it becomes
6. Everyone has an ego bigger than the other just because they have a Ph.D. (please)
7. Full-time faculty have tenure, and some of them need to go already
8. Not much room for growth- you will have to look at other departments or CSUs
9. No training or onboarding whatsoever for new staff; you have to train yourself
10. Raises (IRPs) are regularly denied
11. The Campus can get really hot during the summer months
12. They claim to be very "student-centered", but they are not; some staff don't care because they are frustrated 
13. Some managers and directors can be bullies and will try to intimidate you

pros: Gain experience with TicketMaster software and customer service
cons: Can get boring at times depending if work is busy or slow.

review_title: Student Coordinating Assistant is a great job to have!
pros: Flexible hours Monday - Friday. Weekends off. Learn how to organize events, be a leader, as well as mentor and guide students.
cons: Cons vary depending on which department you work in and personal compatibility with each position.

review_title: Easy job but management had to change
job_title: Student Library Assistant in Northridge, CA
pros: My coworkers were also students and easy to get along with. The supervisors would buy us lunch on longer weekend shifts sometimes. The environment isn't very fast-paced.
cons: Supervisors at the time would ask personal questions that were inappropriate for the workplace, mostly about our religious beliefs. When a group of student assistants came forward to HR about them, they couldn't do anything. A new manager was brought in and he started making great changes right before I stopped working there (end of school semester.) It can be difficult to get patrons out before (or at) closing. It's also a public library, so we get a good amount of homeless patrons. 90% of them don't cause problems, but you might have to wake them up. before closing or handle student complaints regarding them.

review_title: I didn't know such unintelligent people could exist.
pros: They supply housing as compensation.
cons:
They create extra work for those below them to make it seem that they are going above and beyond in their job to their boss.
They pride themselves of every little thing that "they" do... when it's really their staff because they don't lift a finger.
Your hard work will not be recognized unless you go around bragging and over exaggerating to everyone.
They will preach and preach and when it comes down to it they will prove the biggest hypocrites you will ever meet.
They all think they are excellent psychologists, when in fact that is not what their job is about (or shouldn't be). Note - a degree in psychology DOES NOT make you a good psychologist. This is a common misconception here and they just don't get hints either.

pros:
- Great environment because you will be surrounded by studious, intelligent, and driven students and stuff.

-They will give you hours if you ask and the managers are understanding.

- Other employees were very motivational and would give you meaning full advice. 

-Very diverse community.
cons:
-If you work at Freudian Sip Housing it can be very boring because there are moments you will not have any customers.

-If you are new you will get confused and make the wrong drinks. 
(My advice is to study the ingredients with flashcards.)

pros: Good location, lots of places to eat and shop nearby.  Good services on campus, great library, bookstore, shops, etc.  Also a safe campus for the most part.  Good communication from President's Office (and Vice Presidents too) and the campus seems to be run well financially.  Good but expensive parking.
cons: Vicious hot weather in the Summer.  Poor morale of long time employees who gave up on promotions a long time ago!  Don't turn into one of them.  Can function as private company: favorites promoted, long time supervisors pushed to the side near the end of their career and given less important work.

review_title: Experience at the USU at CSUN
job_title: Student Building Manager in Northridge, CA
pros: Great scheduling, flexible and school scheduling is always a priority so you never have to worry about deciding whether or not to work or go to class. Also very easy job.
cons: They don't offer a lot of hours, but that is because of a school regulation code that doesnt allow it. however, during semesters you are off, like summer or winter, you are able to pick up close to 40 hours a week if you are lucky.

job_title: Administrative Analyst, Exempt I in Northridge, CA
pros: Working at a university can be rewarding. There are many events for staff to take advantage of. The benefits are good - CALPERS still provides a pension. Union is good and helpful. I have worked in other places without a union and it was tough not having any union protection - especially if you have children to feed. You can get a really great discount on tuition and complete a degree program without taking out any loans, at any CSU. If you go to school while working you are considered a student are able to use many of the amenities there that students use free of cost - gym, good discounts on tickets (movies, amusement parks), etc. As far work/life balance goes, depending on your role, you can be on the clock at least 60 hours a week. Those are usually roles for middle management. However, I have also noted that work/life balance is an individual effort. Most do not put their foots down and "self-preserve".
cons:
Salaries are not inline with fair market value. The fact that there are jobs at the CSUN, that pay less than $3,000 a month before taxes is ridiculous. CSUN is located in the Los Angeles County and if you know anything about LA county, is the cost of living is much higher than most other US cities. I think the pay scale and classifications needs an overhaul. The only way to make good money is to leave the university and take an a position elsewhere, and have a new salary increase. When you return to the university, they will most likely match your current salary. 

A piece of advice for anyone interviewing at CSUN - negotiate with HR before you accept any position there. If you are hired, you will hear from the HR department with an offer, not anyone on the search committee. You must negotiate with HR for an offer.

pros: As an adjunct instructor of over ten years, I've enjoyed my students at CSUN more than at many other colleges/universities. They are devoted and interested, and while they are often juggling a lot of other responsibilities, I've had great experiences in the classroom with them.
cons: The administration is very concerned with impressing/staying in line with the CSU and sometimes this is at the expense of faculty and students. Same probs as other institutions: you can have your classes canceled late in the game due to low enrollment.

review_title: Neutral experience as a tutor for the engineering department.
pros: Enjoyed having flexible hours during the week and had reasonable pay as a tutor for one of the programs of the engineering department.
cons: Could only work ten hours a week maximum so it was limited pay and had to drive out for weekly meetings on Fridays for an hour, and since I only had a set number of hours and lived far away it was a pain to drive all the way out to the valley.

review_title: It's cushier than more adjunct jobs at community colleges.
job_title: Semester-by-semester Faculty in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Lots of campus resources to support you with your courses and with regulating student conduct, a diverse body of students, and a gorgeous campus.
cons: For semester by semester faculty, no job security, your chances of getting a spring class depend on your likability and who you know in the department.

review_title: Low paying work. Use this position as a stepping stone.
pros:
• You get hands on experience using GIS in a professional setting.  
• Workers have moved on to more professional work.
cons:
• Low to no pay for professional level work.
• Opportunities for growth were limited to select candidates, with a disregard of other workers.
• Lack of communication between upper management and interns.

pros: The cottage studio in Santa Monica gave me great service. They made my music sound awesome! They were kind and friendly to work with and they had access to all the top recording gear.
cons: The only downside of the cottage studio is that they are so busy, it take a while to get scheduled. Not for the short term off the cuff kind of customer.

review_title: Generally Positive Workplace, Significant Financial Problems
pros:
- People at all levels have generally been friendly, and are usually a pleasure to work with
- Students are generally appreciative, and teaching has been very rewarding
- Flexibility to have either a teaching-heavy or research-heavy load, and both can lead to tenure with some care
- (Depends on the department) people generally want you to get tenure, and tenure is granted more often than not, to the point of practically being guaranteed in some departments
cons:
- Pay is low compared to responsibilities, with some local community colleges paying better with fewer job responsibilities
- Constant financial problems which impact work and instruction, including significant workloads (because we can't afford to hire more people), classrooms and related equipment constantly in various states of disrepair (because we can't afford to fix or replace things), and classes with long waitlists (because we can't afford to hire more instructors)
- Pay compression is a major issue; within 5 years, new faculty make over 10% more than existing faculty, and this gets compounded as time goes on
- Related to the prior points, COVID-related state budget cuts have exacerbated the above problems to an extreme. Students generally cannot get classes they need anymore, waitlists are longer than the number of seats, resources have been pulled from necessary functions, and a pay cut anywhere between 5-20% for 3+ years is looming. We have been told that this is typical for all universities, but I know this is not true based on discussions with professors elsewhere.
- Towards addressing funding concerns, grants and sponsored research are getting pushed heavily, and this is largely in conflict with the CSU's mission

pros:
•Being a project assistant, learning newest technology is pretty common. People like to learn new stuff may like to work in this position.
•It's a part time job. Even though the pay is not too excellent, the working hours are flexible and student who like to arrange their working time will love it.
cons:
•The salary of Project Assistant is not too high.
•The promotion of Project Assistant is not good enough.

pros: The benefits of working on campus is that you do not have to commute between work and classes. Managers are typically very lenient in creating your work schedules.
cons: All student assistant positions pay the same, regardless of the type of work it is. Depending on the department, you may be limited to only doing what your position demands. There is little room for growth.

job_title: Library Desk Assistant in Northridge, CA
pros: There are consistent small raises here and there, and you can go wrong with great people to work with! They really treat employees with respect and know how important we all are.
cons: Only allowed 20 hours a week while a student, so having enough money can sometimes be difficult. Also only paid 1 time a month can be difficult to manage, though you get used to it.

job_title: Faculty Technology Student Assistant in Northridge, CA
pros: If you're a student, they work well with you schedule. They have to because you need to have a least a 2.0 GPA to work at the facility. You can only work a max of 20 hours if you're a student. Most likely, they'll try to give you the 20 hours but only if you allow them.
cons:
Can be repetitive.
Worked there for 2.5 years and never got a raise. 
No one gets a raise, I found out that other departments were giving their staff 1,000 month (a lot for a college student).

job_title: Operations and Maintenance in Newbury Park, CA
pros: Cal State Northridge has always been at the leading edge of progress in virtually every area from academics to campus development.  The faculty and staff are among the nicest people I have ever known.
cons: If anything, I would say that there is a absence of enthusiasm by the student body in support of sports programs.

review_title: A great time and an experience of a life time
pros: Great people to work with.  Everyone is lively and all of us love what we are doing.  Everyone is helping each other and watching out for each other like a big family.
cons: The duty hours and calls are too long and boring.  The security team they hired are annoying due to they think they can boss everyone around just because they are in charge of the security.  They yell at residents/working staff all the time.

pros: Good place for entry level and mid level jobs. One can keep good balance between your professional and personal life. One can always enjoy college life side by side.
cons: It all depends what your aspirations are. If you are looking for a big professional career then you may need to move on after few years.

pros: Benefits benefits benefits. This is the only pro about working at any University. Now I'm just trying to reach the 20 word minimum to post
cons:
K.P.! Favoritism to tenured employees. Will let you go for any reason no job security. No room for growth.  You have to literally wait for someone to pass or retire to move up.
Pay is way below market rates.

review_title: A Chill and comfortable place to work
job_title: Administrative Student Assistant in Northridge, CA
pros: The culture of CSUN is very chill and everyone is so nice to each other, and typical here, is clock on 8 clock off 5. No competing no random stuff. Also you will learn a lot if you work as a student especially you will encounter 70% of the problems are from the students.
cons: Lack of motivations,  professional wise, it is not like company who has to be super professional otherwise nobody buying you.

pros: Flexible schedule, and also there were a select few students who really cared about their performance. Those students were a motivation to review the professors materials prior to work.
cons: the hours that were the most busy were those just prior to exams. The nature of the job, but still annoying.

pros: Any position at the USU is incredibly rewarding professionally and academically, allowing the student employees to perform at their best. The USU gives its student employees many hands on experiences they can use in their future careers. Best place to work if you're attending college at Cal State Northridge!
cons: The amount of free food you get from working here will result in weight gain!

job_title: Graphic Design Student Assistant in Northridge, CA
pros: I loved working at Student Marketing and Communications on the Cal State Northridge campus because I got to meet and work with some May different people in various fields out side of my own. The was always a great atmosphere with a great group of people to work with.
cons: There really where no cons, I worked on all sorts of different projects with amazing people and I enjoyed going to work every single day.

review_title: VPAC Review -- Good job for a student who lives on/nearby campus

pros: They are very flexible with the scheduling if you are a student. Great people to work with and management was even good too. Rare to come by these days.

review_title: Great people but higher ups in admin can be difficult

cons: Low pay, higher admin can be difficult and so can faculty. Only get paid once a month and it's hard to move up or get promotions

pros: No matter how many mistakes the administration makes it can't fail because it is a government institution.
cons: Clueless administration. Insufficient budget. Unrealistic expectations. Constant hypocrisy by leadership.

pros: Great opportunity for connections. I’ve met so many people here and have gotten letters of recommendation as well. They really prepare you for the real world. Very flexible with school.
cons: Doesn’t really help your resume as much when you worked on campus. It’s great working at your school but I think it’s also valuable to get experience off campus.

pros: Associated Students of CSUN is a great organization who firmly believes that students come first. Students are involved at every level of decision making. If you like working in a professional learning environment, this is the place for you!
cons: There wasn't always enough for me to do. Most of my projects were intense at the beginning, but slowed down after the initial work was done.

job_title: Student Clerical Assistant in Northridge, CA

The student union also provides opportunities for career growth as an employee as well and the work environment is both helpful and motivating.
cons: There are no cons to think of from this employment.

review_title: Good People, But a Bit Disorganized

pros:
• Other than having to set-up during a scheduled time for less than an hour a week, we were able to completely set our own hours

cons:
• Only real con was the low pay, which from looking at more recent reviews, was raised in most departments after I left (not by much, but it's something)!
• No real room to advance (understandably)

pros: Relatively relaxed environment. Promotes self initiative and hard work.
cons: The pay is horrible depending on what you do and part-time schedules change every two weeks meaning you can be closing until midnight for a week then be expected to come in at 5:45am for the next week. It messed up my sleep and study habits.

review_title: I love the people I work with!
pros:
Very Flexible with school schedule!
Very friendly people! I will be sad when I graduate and have to quit.

Gets kind of boring.

pros: Very supportive work environment.  Teachers are helpful.  Collaborative assistance available when needed.

pros: It is like a small town in itself where we meet different types of people with diverse communities.

pros: For my position I didn't have a set schedule to work. I worked when I felt like it. I only had to finish tasks by the deadline.

pros: Collaboration across divisions, people really want to do what is best for their students, great benefits.
